The Brontë family is an exceptional family
but, in a way, it's Emily Brontë whose the

41.text:
most exceptional of them all really - the
most singular, the most independent minded

47.text:
and her teacher, Monsieur Heger in Brussels,
said she should have been a great navigator

54.text:
and she's got all that kind of spirit to her
of independent mindedness and finding new

59.text:
worlds and so the wonderful thing about Wuthering
Heights is the way that it - in one way it

66.text:
is the most disciplined and complexly organised
novel. If you try and work out its back story

73.text:
and its time scheme, it's beautifully structured
and organised and the way it's told - it's

80.text:
got so many different narrators - it's like
a little set of Chinese boxes set inside each

84.text:
other. So, in one way it's wonderfully controlled
and organised and at the same time, it seems

90.text:
to touch the most kind of primitive and deep
human feelings about the nature of human culture

98.text:
- what happens when human culture meets something
beyond it, itself - and again, it's quite

106.text:
a realistic novel - so Lockwood at the beginning
- he's like somebody from Jane Austen and

111.text:
then he walks into Wuthering Heights and he
keeps getting it wrong. You know, he sees

118.text:
some dead rabbits and he thinks they're kittens.
He thinks they all must belong to the same

122.text:
family. Well, they all do, but none in the
relationships that he thinks that they do

127.text:
- so he constantly misunderstands it, because
he's in a world that touches much more powerful

132.text:
and primitive kinds of feelings. So, Emily
Brontë, like her siblings, creates these

140.text:
fantasy worlds. So here is the little Grammar
of Geography that they had as children and

146.text:
in it you can see that they've written the
word Gondal, like it was a real place and

151.text:
that was the fantasy world that she created
with Anne. And again, like her sister, Charlotte,

158.text:
she brings lots of Gothic elements, lots of
fantasy elements, lots of fairytale elements

162.text:
into the novel, but within that very disciplined
kind of framework.

166.text:
So, think of Heathcliff, for example. In one
way he behaves in a totally realistic way.

171.text:
You can see where he lives, you can see the
way he speaks and so forth, but in another

176.text:
way, he's deeply mysterious and seems to touch
all sorts of supernatural, or near supernatural

181.text:
forces. Nobody knows where he's born, nobody
knows who his parents are, he's only got one

188.text:
name - he's just called Heathcliff. Why should
he have that? And people call him an afreet

193.text:
or a ghoul, he seems to be in touch with satanic
kinds of forces. He digs up Cathy at the end

200.text:
and wants to be buried with her. He seems
to be able to choose his own death. People

204.text:
say that he's walking at the end. So, all
these kind of Gothic elements and yet they're

209.text:
never fully supernatural - they just seem
to haunt the edges of the book, haunt the

215.text:
characterisation of it, so that it's constantly
under control, in that you get the power and

221.text:
the emotional force and the eroticism of Gothic
in this novel, but at the same time, with

228.text:
all the realistic power of a novel that seizes
you as if it could really be true.
